com.googlecode.kevinarpe.papaya
Class StringUtils

java.lang.Object
  com.googlecode.kevinarpe.papaya.StringUtils

public final class StringUtils
extends Object

Collection of static methods to manipulate String references.

Author:
Kevin Connor ARPE (kevinarpe@gmail.com)

Field Detail

NEW_LINE

public static final String NEW_LINE
This is the current newline: System.getProperty("line.separator"). This will differ between operating systems, such as UNIX variants and Microsoft Windows.

It is also available when calling String.format(String, Object...) and using %n in the format string.

See Also:
NEW_LINE, UNIX_NEW_LINE, WINDOWS_NEW_LINE, NEW_LINE_REGEX

NEW_LINE_REGEX

public static final Pattern NEW_LINE_REGEX
This is the current newline as a compiled regular expression: Pattern.compile(Pattern.quote(NEW_LINE))

See Also:
NEW_LINE

UNIX_NEW_LINE

public static final String UNIX_NEW_LINE
This is the newline used by UNIX variants: "\n". This value will never differ between operating systems.

WINDOWS_NEW_LINE

public static final String WINDOWS_NEW_LINE
This is the newline used by Microsoft Windows: "\r\n". This value will never differ between operating systems.

Method Detail

parseBoolean

@FullyTested
public static boolean parseBoolean(String str)
Strictly converts a string to a boolean value. Ignoring case, only "true" and "false" are accepted as valid values. The built-in Java method, Boolean.parseBoolean(String), is more lenient, treating "true" (or case variants) as true and all other values, including null, as false.

Parameters:
str - input value
Returns:
boolean value
Throws:
NullPointerException - if str is null
IllegalArgumentException - if str is not "true" or "false", ignoring case
See Also:
FuncUtils.PARSE_BOOLEAN_FROM_STRING

trimWhitespacePrefix

@FullyTested
public static String trimWhitespacePrefix(String str)
Removes all leading whitespace chars. To be precise, "leading" is always defined as starting from index zero. This terminology may be backwards for right-to-left languages such as Hebrew, Arabic, and Farsi.

Whitespace is defined as Character.isWhitespace(char), which will include all Unicode whitespace, such as the Japanese full-width space.

If zero leading whitespace chars are found, the input string reference is returned. If all characters in input string are whitespace, an empty string is returned.

Parameters:
str - a string reference
Returns:
string reference without leading whitespace chars
Throws:
NullPointerException - if str is null
See Also:
trimWhitespaceSuffix(String)

trimWhitespaceSuffix

@FullyTested
public static String trimWhitespaceSuffix(String str)
Removes all trailing whitespace chars. To be precise, "trailing" is always defined as starting from the last index. This terminology may be backwards for right-to-left languages such as Hebrew, Arabic, and Farsi.

Whitespace is defined by Character.isWhitespace(char), which includes all special whitespace chars used in East Asian languages.

If zero leading whitespace chars are found, the input string reference is returned. If all characters in input string are whitespace, an empty string is returned.

Parameters:
str - a string reference
Returns:
string reference without leading whitespace chars
Throws:
NullPointerException - if str is null
See Also:
trimWhitespacePrefix(String)

isEmptyOrWhitespace

@FullyTested
public static <T extends CharSequence> boolean isEmptyOrWhitespace(String str)
Tests if an input string is empty or only whitespace chars.

Whitespace is defined by Character.isWhitespace(char), which includes all special whitespace chars used in East Asian languages.

Parameters:
str - input string
Returns:
true if empty or all whitespace
Throws:
NullPointerException - if str is null

substringPrefix

@FullyTested
public static String substringPrefix(String str,
                                                 int count)
This method is modeled after Left() from Visual Basic. Copies a specified number of leading chars from a string. To be precise, "leading" is always defined as starting from index zero. This terminology may be backwards for right-to-left languages such as Hebrew, Arabic, and Farsi.

If count == 0, the empty string is retured. If count >= str.length(), the input string reference is returned.

Parameters:
str - input string reference to process
count - number of chars to copy starting from first index. Must be >= 0, and may be greater than input length
Returns:
string reference created from leading chars
Throws:
NullPointerException - if str is null
IllegalArgumentException - if count is negative

substringSuffix

@FullyTested
public static String substringSuffix(String str,
                                                 int count)
This method is modeled after Right() from Visual Basic. Copies a specified number of trailing chars from a string. To be precise, "trailing" is always defined as starting from the last index. This terminology may be backwards for right-to-left languages such as Hebrew, Arabic, and Farsi.

If count == 0, the empty string is retured. If count >= str.length(), the input string reference is returned.

Parameters:
str - input string reference to process
count - number of chars to copy starting from last index. Must be >= 0, and may be greater than input length
Returns:
string reference created from trailing chars
Throws:
NullPointerException - if str is null
IllegalArgumentException - if count is negative

removeCharAt

@FullyTested
public static String removeCharAt(String str,
                                              int index)
This is a convenience method for removeByIndexAndCount(String, int, int) where count = 1.

removeByIndexAndCount

@NotFullyTested
public static String removeByIndexAndCount(String str,
                                                          int index,
                                                          int count)
Removes characters from a string by creating a new string and copying remaining characters from the source string. To be precise, using the term "remove" is a misnomer, as Java strings cannot change size; they are immutable.

If count == 0, the input string reference is returned. No copy is made.

Parameters:
str - a string reference. May be empty, but not null
index - offset to begin removing characters. Range: 0 to str.length() - 1
count - number of characters to remove. Must be non-negative.
Returns:
reference to a string with characters removed
Throws:
NullPointerException - if str is null
IllegalArgumentException -
  • if str is empty
  • if count < 0
IndexOutOfBoundsException -
  • if index < 0
  • if index >= str.length()
  • if index + count > str.length()
See Also:
StringArgs.checkIndexAndCount(CharSequence, int, int, String, String, String)

addPrefixPerLine

@FullyTested
public static String addPrefixPerLine(String textBlock,
                                                  String optLinePrefix,
                                                  StringUtils.TextProcessorOption... optionArr)
This is a convenience method to call addPrefixAndSuffixPerLine(String, String, String, TextProcessorOption...) with optLineSuffix as null.

addSuffixPerLine

@FullyTested
public static String addSuffixPerLine(String textBlock,
                                                  String optLineSuffix,
                                                  StringUtils.TextProcessorOption... optionArr)
This is a convenience method to call addPrefixAndSuffixPerLine(String, String, String, TextProcessorOption...) with optLinePrefix as null.

addPrefixAndSuffixPerLine

@FullyTested
public static String addPrefixAndSuffixPerLine(String textBlock,
                                                           String optLinePrefix,
                                                           String optLineSuffix,
                                                           StringUtils.TextProcessorOption... optionArr)
Creates a new string from a multiline block of text with additional prefix and/or suffix per line. This method can be used to programatically indent blocks of text.

Example:
String textBlock = String.format("This is a sample%nmultiline block%nof text.");
(The format code "%n" is replaced by current system newline.) 

 This is a sample
 multiline block
 of text.
Calling this method with optLinePrefix as ">" and optLineSuffix as "<" will return: 
 >This is a sample<
 >multiline block<
 >of text.<

Parameters:
textBlock -
  • text to process, usually a multiline block of text
  • text is split and joined using NEW_LINE
  • if text ends with NEW_LINE:
    • final "phantom" empty line is ignored during processing
    • result will also end with NEW_LINE
  • must not be null or empty
optLinePrefix -
  • additional text to add to the beginning to each line in the multiline block of text
  • may be null or empty, but only if parameter optLineSuffix is not also null or empty
optLineSuffix -
  • additional text to add to the end to each line in the multiline block of text
  • may be null or empty, but only if parameter optLinePrefix is not also null or empty
optionArr -
  • zero or more values from enum StringUtils.TextProcessorOption
  • values must not be null
Returns:
new string with each line modified to have new prefix and/or suffix
Throws:
NullPointerException -
  • if textBlock is null
  • if any element of optionArr is null
IllegalArgumentException -
  • if textBlock has length zero (empty)
  • if both optLinePrefix and optLineSuffix are null or empty
See Also:
addPrefixPerLine(String, String, TextProcessorOption...), addSuffixPerLine(String, String, TextProcessorOption...)
